bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, October 3, 1918

div1.p: Carter discusses his travel schedule and the dangers of influenza.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, October 3, 1918
div1.p:
“I write to inform you that these few lines
leave me well & hope that they find you
enjoying the same blessing"- There I came
here yesterday morning- I am proposing
to go to Petersburg tonight getting there
tomorrow morning- Thence to Balt. Sun-
day I judge. I ought to go to Camp Hum-
phreys - but think I had best go there from
Baltimore- not earlier than Oct 10- or 12
I may however as I must pass through
Alexandria- stop then on my way
up - which would put me in Baltimore
2
Wednesday.

There is much Influenza - in Portsmouth
same here, much I judge & I presume
in Petersburg. I was not consciously
exposed to any in Portsmouth or Norfolk.
Possibly have been here, but not de-
cidedly. The disease here is unusually mild - more than elsewhere. Also I took the fourth dose
of vaccine last night. I went to see
- James Martin & Dixie Tuesday night
This is why I write. The main risk of
the influenza seems to be in Weak-
ened people. You then either-Stop
your work: or let down on in so as to
let it give you no trouble, & rest
up
3
rest up- Lie down after meals
& this will get your digestion in
order-or half to-& that will improve your
health & strengthen you. Same for Mary

I am taking all the pains that I can
you need not send any mail to
me, but hold it. If Carter Redd writes
you can send that to Peters'g
Love to Mrs. Ma: Aunt Mary & Jennie
